outputs.description: Voronoi value: F1, F2−F1, edge, or cell ID depending on Output mode

node:worley-noise.title: Worley Noise
node:worley-noise.tagline: Cellular noise with F1, F2−F1, or edge output for organic and crystal-like patterns
node:worley-noise.description: Generates Worley (cellular) noise using the same grid-and-jitter structure as Voronoi. Output mode: F1 (distance to nearest point), F2−F1 (difference to second-nearest), or edge (smooth cell boundaries). Use for organic textures, scales, or abstract cellular patterns. Scale, jitter, and distance metric (Euclidean, Manhattan, Chebyshev) are in the Worley group; output mode and intensity in Output.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to sample the Worley pattern

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Worley value: F1, F2−F1, or edge depending on Output mode

node:wave-patterns.title: Wave Patterns
node:wave-patterns.tagline: Perfect for creating animated wave patterns with customizable frequency, amplitude, and direction
node:wave-patterns.description: Generates wave patterns using trigonometric functions (sine, cosine) to create repeating, oscillating patterns. The waves can be oriented in different directions, have configurable frequency (how many waves), amplitude (wave height), and can be animated over time. Multiple wave layers can be combined to create complex interference patterns. This is ideal for creating water effects, animated backgrounds, or any repeating wave-like patterns. The waves can be linear (traveling in one direction) or radial (expanding from a center point).

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to generate waves from

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The wave pattern value (typically -1.0 to 1.0 range)

node:flow-field-pattern.title: Flow Field
node:flow-field-pattern.tagline: Curl-noise-based flow pattern for organic streaks and flow lines
node:flow-field-pattern.description: Generates a flow-like pattern using 2D curl noise: the curl of a scalar noise field gives a divergence-free vector field, whose magnitude is mapped to a 0–1 float suitable for color mapping. Parameters control spatial scale, curl sampling scale, time speed, octaves, and output intensity. Ideal for organic, fluid-like backgrounds and streak effects.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: Input UV coordinates to sample the flow field

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Flow pattern value (0–1 range) for color map or mixing

node:stripes.title: Stripes
node:stripes.tagline: Directional alternating bands with configurable angle, frequency, and sharp or soft edges
node:stripes.description: Generates directional stripe patterns by rotating the input coordinates and creating alternating bands along one axis. Control the stripe angle (direction), frequency (number of bands), and sharpness (0 for soft gradients, 1 for hard edges). Optional phase and time speed allow animation when time is wired from the graph. Output is a float suitable for color map or mix.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to generate stripes from

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The stripe pattern value (0.0 to 1.0)

node:dots.title: Dots
node:dots.tagline: Polka-dot grid pattern with configurable spacing, dot size, and falloff
node:dots.description: Generates a seamless grid of dots (polka-dot pattern) by tiling the plane and drawing a circular dot in each cell. Control the spacing between dots, the dot size (radius), and the falloff (softness of the edge). The pattern tiles seamlessly and outputs a float suitable for color map or mix.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to generate the dot grid from

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The dot pattern value (0.0 to 1.0)

node:reaction-diffusion.title: Reaction-Diffusion
node:reaction-diffusion.tagline: Gray-Scott-style reaction-diffusion for organic blob and cell patterns
node:reaction-diffusion.description: Generates organic, cell-like patterns using a Gray-Scott reaction-diffusion model. The simulation runs 1–2 steps per pixel from a noise seed (single-pass; no multi-pass buffers). Adjust feed and kill rates to change the structure; diffusion A/B control spread. Scale maps UV into simulation space; time speed animates the seed for evolving patterns. Output is a float 0–1 (activator concentration) suitable for color map or mix.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to sample the pattern

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The pattern value (0.0 to 1.0)

node:gradient.title: Gradient
node:gradient.tagline: Radial or linear gradient (float 0–1) for vignettes, orbs, and linear fades
node:gradient.description: Outputs a single float gradient in 0–1 range. Radial mode: gradient from center with configurable radius and falloff (smoothstep). Linear mode: gradient along an angle with scale. Use with color map, mix, or smoothstep for vignettes, orbs, and directional fades.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to sample the gradient

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The gradient value (0.0 to 1.0)

node:radial-rays.title: Radial Rays
node:radial-rays.tagline: N rays from a center point with count, spread, width, and falloff
node:radial-rays.description: Generates a radial ray pattern: N evenly spaced rays emanating from a center point. Control ray count, angular spread (full circle or arc), ray width, edge falloff, and rotation. Output is a float suitable for blending or mixing with color maps. Ideal for sunbursts, starbursts, and radial light effects.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: Input 2D coordinates (e.g. UV)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Ray pattern value (0.0 to 1.0)

node:sunbeams.title: Sunbeams
node:sunbeams.tagline: Directional beams at an angle for light streaks and god-ray style effects
node:sunbeams.description: Produces directional parallel beams at a configurable angle. Control beam count, spread (frequency along the perpendicular axis), width, softness, and intensity. Output is a float for blending. Use with mix or multiply for sunbeam overlays and directional light streaks.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: Input 2D coordinates (e.g. UV)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Beam pattern value (0.0 to 1.0)

node:crepuscular-rays.title: Crepuscular Rays
node:crepuscular-rays.tagline: Atmospheric rays from a source point with distance falloff
node:crepuscular-rays.description: Generates crepuscular (atmospheric) rays from a source point. Rays radiate from the source with configurable count, spread, and width. Distance falloff attenuates the rays with distance from the source (1/(1 + dist*k)), giving a natural volumetric look. Animation: rotation speed (turns per second) and rotation offset (phase in turns) for continuous rotating rays. Ideal for sun-through-clouds and god-ray effects.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: Input 2D coordinates (e.g. UV)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Ray pattern value with distance falloff (0.0 to 1.0)

node:gradient-mask.title: Gradient Mask
node:gradient-mask.tagline: Ideal for creating smooth gradient masks for selective effect application and blending
node:gradient-mask.description: Creates gradient masks that can selectively apply or blend effects in specific regions. The node supports multiple mask types: radial (circular gradients from a center point), linear (gradients along a direction), and elliptical (oval-shaped gradients). Each mask type has configurable position, size, falloff, and strength parameters. The mask outputs a value from 0.0 (fully masked) to 1.0 (fully visible), allowing smooth transitions. This is essential for creating vignettes, spotlight effects, or any region-based effect application.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input color to apply the gradient mask to

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The masked color output with gradient blending applied

node:hexagonal-grid.title: Hexagons
node:hexagonal-grid.tagline: Perfect for creating hexagonal grid patterns for tiling, cellular structures, or game board layouts
node:hexagonal-grid.description: Generates a seamless, regular hexagonal tiling pattern. Control the cell size, the gap (margin) between cells, and a per-cell rotation (rotates each hexagon’s shape without rotating the grid). A separate grid rotation rotates the overall tiling, and intensity controls the output strength.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to generate the hexagonal grid from

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The hexagonal grid pattern value

node:simplex-noise.title: Simplex Noise
node:simplex-noise.tagline: Ideal for generating high-quality, smooth noise patterns with better computational efficiency than Perlin noise
node:simplex-noise.description: Generates Simplex noise, an improved version of Perlin noise that provides smoother, higher-quality results with better computational performance. Simplex noise uses a different grid structure (simplices instead of hypercubes) that eliminates directional artifacts and provides more uniform distribution. The noise is smoother and more natural-looking than traditional Perlin noise, making it ideal for textures, terrain generation, or any application requiring high-quality procedural noise. The pattern can be scaled, offset, and animated over time.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to sample the Simplex noise

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The Simplex noise value (typically -1.0 to 1.0 range)

node:simplex-3d.title: 3D Simplex Volume
node:simplex-3d.tagline: 3D volume noise (UV + time as Z) for clouds, marble, and animated volume effects
node:simplex-3d.description: Samples 3D Simplex noise using the input UV as X,Y and time as the third dimension (Z). Produces smooth, animated volume-style patterns ideal for clouds, marble, fog, or any effect that should vary in depth over time. Parameters control scale, octaves (fBm layers), lacunarity, gain, time speed, and output intensity. Use with color map, mix, or volume-style nodes for full effect.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: Input UV coordinates (X,Y of the 3D sample position)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: 3D Simplex noise value in 0–1 range

node:particle-system.title: Particle System
node:particle-system.tagline: Perfect for creating animated particle effects with configurable movement, size, and behavior
node:particle-system.description: Generates animated particle systems that create dynamic, moving particle effects. Each particle has position, velocity, size, and lifetime properties that evolve over time. The particles can be rendered as points, circles, or other shapes, and can interact with forces, boundaries, or other particles. The system supports configurable particle count, spawn rate, initial velocity, gravity, and various behaviors. This is ideal for creating effects like sparks, smoke, rain, or any collection of moving elements.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to render particles at

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The particle system output (particle presence or density)

node:plane-grid.title: Grid
node:plane-grid.tagline: Ideal for creating regular square grid patterns for tiling, organization, or structural elements
node:plane-grid.description: Generates regular square grid patterns by dividing space into uniform cells. The grid creates a checkerboard or lattice-like pattern that can be used for tiling, organization, or as a structural element in compositions. You can control the grid cell size, line thickness, and offset. The grid can output cell IDs, distance to grid lines, or edge detection. This is useful for creating game boards, measurement grids, or any application requiring regular spatial division.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to generate the grid from

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The grid pattern value

node:box-torus-sdf.title: SDF
node:box-torus-sdf.tagline: 3D primitives (box, torus, capsule, cylinder, cone, round cone, octahedron) using signed distance fields and raymarching
node:box-torus-sdf.description: Renders 3D primitives using signed distance fields (SDF) with raymarching. Shape types: 0=Box, 1=Torus, 2=Capsule, 3=Cylinder (capped; radius X, half-height Y), 4=Cone (height Y, base radius X, top radius Z), 5=Round cone (base X, tip radius Z, height Y), 6=Octahedron (scale X). All share Position, Size, Rotation, and Appearance (glow, raymarch steps). SDF raymarching provides smooth, accurate 3D geometry. Essential for building 3D scenes in a 2D shader.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input UV coordinates to raymarch from

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The SDF raymarched shape result (signed distance value)

node:cylinder-cone.title: Cylinder & Cone
node:cylinder-cone.tagline: 3D cylinder and cone primitives using signed distance fields and raymarching
node:cylinder-cone.description: Renders 3D cylinder and cone shapes using signed distance fields (SDF) with raymarching. Choose Cylinder (radius and height) or Cone (base radius and height). Position, size, and rotation groups match the SDF node pattern. Use UV as input; output is a float suitable for mix, color-map, or final output. Ideal for pillars, cones, and rounded 3D primitives in a 2D shader.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: Input UV coordinates to raymarch from

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: SDF raymarched result (distance-based value with glow)

node:box-2d.title: Box 2D
node:box-2d.tagline: Axis-aligned 2D rectangle or rounded rectangle as a mask for compositing and shapes
node:box-2d.description: Outputs a 2D axis-aligned rectangle or rounded rectangle as a float mask. Use UV (or any vec2) as input; the node centers the box at the given position with configurable width and height. Roundness 0 gives a sharp rectangle; values greater than 0 produce rounded corners. Softness controls the edge falloff and intensity scales the output. Ideal for panels, buttons, or building compound 2D shapes. For rotation, use a transform node upstream.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: Input 2D coordinates (e.g. UV) to sample the box

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Box mask (0.0 outside, up to intensity inside; soft edges by softness)

node:metaballs.title: Metaballs
node:metaballs.tagline: 3D raymarched metaballs: soft blobs that blend where their fields overlap
node:metaballs.description: Renders 3D metaballs using raymarching. Metaballs are soft blobs whose influence fields are summed; the visible surface is where the combined field exceeds a threshold. Blob count (2–6), radius, threshold, and orbit radius control the shape; blobs orbit around the scene center. Use Position to move the group, Animation for orbit speed, and Appearance for raymarch steps and glow. Connect UV to in and out to color-map or mix for shading.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: UV coordinates to raymarch from (e.g. from UV Coords)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Surface and glow value (float); use with color-map or mix

node:sky-dome.title: Sky / Dome
node:sky-dome.tagline: Procedural sky dome with zenith/horizon gradient and optional sun disc for backgrounds
node:sky-dome.description: Outputs a procedural sky as vec4 (RGBA) suitable for use behind raymarched 3D scenes. Sky color is blended from horizon to zenith; an optional sun disc is added when the view ray is close to the sun direction. Use Sky group to set zenith and horizon RGB and horizon sharpness; use Sun group to set direction (X,Y,Z), radius (radians), and intensity. Connect UV (e.g. from UV Coords) to in; connect out to mix, final output, or blend-mode nodes.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: UV coordinates to compute sky ray direction (e.g. from UV Coords)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: Sky color (RGB) and alpha 1.0

node:blending-modes.title: Blending Modes
node:blending-modes.tagline: Ideal for combining elements using various blend modes like multiply, screen, overlay, and more
node:blending-modes.description: Applies blending modes to combine two color inputs, similar to layer blending in image editing software. The node supports multiple blend modes including Normal, Multiply, Screen, Overlay, Soft Light, Hard Light, Color Dodge, Color Burn, and more. Each mode produces different visual effects when combining colors. The blend can be controlled by opacity, and the blend source can come from the second input, a constant value, noise, or wave patterns. This is essential for creating complex compositing effects and layering multiple elements together.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The base color to blend with the blend input

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The blended color result

node:block-displacement.title: Block Displacement
node:block-displacement.tagline: Perfect for creating glitch effects with variable-size blocks that displace coordinates
node:block-displacement.description: Creates glitch effects by dividing the coordinate space into variable-size blocks and applying displacement offsets. Larger blocks receive less offset while smaller blocks receive more offset, creating a distinctive glitch aesthetic. The blocks can be oriented horizontally or vertically, and the block boundaries, sizes, and offsets are determined by configurable parameters including block count, spacing chaos, and time-based animation. This effect is commonly used with block-color-glitch and block-edge-brightness nodes to create cohesive glitch compositions.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input 2D coordinates to apply block displacement to

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The displaced coordinates after block transformation

node:compare.title: Compare
node:compare.tagline: Perfect for comparing two values and outputting binary results for conditional logic
node:compare.description: Compares two input values using a selected comparison operation and outputs 1.0 if the condition is true, 0.0 otherwise. The available operations include equal (==), not equal (!=), less than (<), less than or equal (<=), greater than (>), and greater than or equal (>=). This is essential for creating conditional logic, thresholds, and binary masks based on value comparisons. The output can be used to drive other nodes or create selective effects.

inputs.name: a
inputs.description: The first value to compare

inputs.name: b
inputs.description: The second value to compare against

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: 1.0 if the comparison is true, 0.0 otherwise

node:select.title: Select
node:select.tagline: Ideal for choosing between two values based on a condition for conditional routing
node:select.description: Selects between two input values based on a condition. If the condition is greater than 0.5, it returns the true value; otherwise, it returns the false value. This creates a simple conditional branch that allows routing different values through the node graph based on conditions. The condition is typically a float value from 0.0 to 1.0, where values above 0.5 are considered true. This is useful for creating conditional effects, switching between different inputs, or implementing if-else logic in shader graphs.

inputs.name: condition
inputs.description: The condition value (values > 0.5 select trueValue)

inputs.name: trueValue
inputs.description: The value returned when condition is true

inputs.name: falseValue
inputs.description: The value returned when condition is false

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The selected value based on the condition

node:one-minus.title: One Minus
node:one-minus.tagline: Perfect for inverting values in the 0-1 range (calculates 1.0 - input)
node:one-minus.description: Subtracts the input value from 1.0, effectively inverting values in the 0-1 range. When the input is 0.0, the output is 1.0; when the input is 1.0, the output is 0.0. This is commonly used for inverting masks, flipping gradients, or creating inverse relationships. The operation is equivalent to (1.0 - input) and is a fundamental utility for many shader operations that require inverted values.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to invert (subtract from 1.0)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The inverted value (1.0 - input)

node:negate.title: Negate
node:negate.tagline: Use this to negate (flip sign) of a value, converting positive to negative and vice versa
node:negate.description: Negates the input value by multiplying it by -1.0, effectively flipping its sign. Positive values become negative, and negative values become positive. Zero remains zero. This is useful for reversing directions, inverting offsets, or creating mirror effects. The operation is equivalent to (-input) and is a fundamental utility for many mathematical operations.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to negate

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The negated value (-input)

node:reciprocal.title: Reciprocal
node:reciprocal.tagline: Ideal for calculating the reciprocal (1.0 / input) for division operations
node:reciprocal.description: Calculates the reciprocal of the input value by dividing 1.0 by the input. The reciprocal of a number is its multiplicative inverse, so multiplying a value by its reciprocal equals 1.0. This is useful for inverting scales, converting rates to periods, or performing division when you need to multiply by the inverse. Be careful with values near zero, as the reciprocal approaches infinity.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to calculate the reciprocal of (must not be zero)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The reciprocal value (1.0 / input)

node:remap.title: Remap
node:remap.tagline: Perfect for remapping values from one range to another with linear interpolation
node:remap.description: Remaps a value from an input range to an output range using linear interpolation. The node takes the input value, determines its position within the input range (inMin to inMax), and maps that position to the corresponding value in the output range (outMin to outMax). This is essential for converting values between different scales, normalizing data, or adjusting value ranges to fit specific requirements. The remapping preserves the relative position of the value within its range.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to remap from the input range

inputs.name: inMin
inputs.description: The minimum value of the input range

inputs.name: inMax
inputs.description: The maximum value of the input range

inputs.name: outMin
inputs.description: The minimum value of the output range

inputs.name: outMax
inputs.description: The maximum value of the output range

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The remapped value in the output range

node:clamp-01.title: Clamp 01
node:clamp-01.tagline: Use this to clamp values to the 0.0-1.0 range, ensuring they stay within valid bounds
node:clamp-01.description: Clamps the input value to the range 0.0 to 1.0. Values below 0.0 become 0.0, values above 1.0 become 1.0, and values within the range remain unchanged. This is a specialized version of the clamp node with fixed bounds, commonly used in shader programming. It's equivalent to clamp(input, 0.0, 1.0) and is essential for ensuring values stay within normalized ranges, particularly for colors, masks, and blend factors.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to clamp to 0.0-1.0 range

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The clamped value (between 0.0 and 1.0)

node:saturate.title: Saturate
node:saturate.tagline: Same as Clamp 01, a common shader programming term for clamping to 0-1 range
node:saturate.description: Saturates the input value by clamping it to the 0.0-1.0 range. This is identical to the Clamp 01 node but uses the common shader programming term 'saturate'. The function ensures values stay within the normalized range, which is essential for color channels, blend factors, and many shader operations. Values below 0.0 become 0.0, values above 1.0 become 1.0, and values within range remain unchanged.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to saturate (clamp to 0.0-1.0)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The saturated value (clamped between 0.0 and 1.0)

node:sign.title: Sign
node:sign.tagline: Ideal for extracting the sign of a value, returning -1.0, 0.0, or 1.0
node:sign.description: Returns the sign of the input value: -1.0 for negative values, 0.0 for zero, and 1.0 for positive values. This is useful for determining direction, creating conditional logic based on sign, or extracting the sign component of a value. The sign function is commonly used in mathematical operations where you need to know whether a value is positive or negative without caring about its magnitude.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to get the sign of

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The sign value (-1.0, 0.0, or 1.0)

node:round.title: Round
node:round.tagline: Perfect for rounding values to the nearest integer for quantization and discrete steps
node:round.description: Rounds the input value to the nearest integer. Values exactly halfway between integers round to the nearest even integer (banker's rounding). This is useful for quantizing values, creating discrete steps, or converting continuous values to integer-like values. Rounding is commonly used for pixel-perfect effects, grid snapping, or creating stepped animations.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to round to the nearest integer

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The rounded value (nearest integer)

node:truncate.title: Truncate
node:truncate.tagline: Use this to truncate (remove fractional part) of a value, rounding towards zero
node:truncate.description: Truncates the input value by removing its fractional part, effectively rounding towards zero. Positive values are rounded down, and negative values are rounded up (towards zero). This is different from floor, which always rounds down. Truncation is useful for creating discrete values, quantizing, or extracting the integer component of a number. The result is always closer to zero than the input.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The value to truncate (remove fractional part)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The truncated value (fractional part removed)

node:lerp.title: Lerp
node:lerp.tagline: Linear interpolation (alias for Mix) for smoothly blending between two values
node:lerp.description: Performs linear interpolation (lerp) between two values, which is identical to the Mix node. When the blend factor (t) is 0.0, it returns the first value (a). When t is 1.0, it returns the second value (b). Values in between are linearly interpolated. The term 'lerp' is commonly used in game development and graphics programming as shorthand for linear interpolation. This node provides the same functionality as Mix but with a different name for familiarity.

inputs.name: a
inputs.description: The first value (returned when t = 0.0)

inputs.name: b
inputs.description: The second value (returned when t = 1.0)

inputs.name: t
inputs.description: The blend factor (typically 0.0 to 1.0)

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The linearly interpolated value between a and b

node:swizzle.title: Swizzle
node:swizzle.tagline: Perfect for reordering and rearranging vector components (xy, yx, xyz, etc.)
node:swizzle.description: Reorders and rearranges vector components using swizzle patterns. Swizzling allows you to access vector components in different orders, duplicate components, or extract subsets. Common patterns include 'xy' (extract x and y), 'yx' (swap x and y), 'xyz' (extract first three), 'zyx' (reverse order), 'xyzw' (all components), and 'wzyx' (reverse all). The node supports common 2, 3, and 4 component patterns. This is essential for manipulating vector data, extracting specific components, or reordering coordinates.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input vector to swizzle

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The swizzled vector with reordered components

node:split-vector.title: Split Vector
node:split-vector.tagline: Ideal for splitting a vector into its individual components (x, y, z, w)
node:split-vector.description: Splits a vector into its individual components, outputting each component (x, y, z, w) as separate float outputs. This allows you to access and manipulate individual components of a vector independently. The node takes a vec4 input and outputs four float values representing the x, y, z, and w components. This is essential for extracting specific components, performing per-component operations, or routing individual components to different parts of the node graph.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The vector to split into components

outputs.name: x
outputs.description: The x component of the input vector

outputs.name: y
outputs.description: The y component of the input vector

outputs.name: z
outputs.description: The z component of the input vector

outputs.name: w
outputs.description: The w component of the input vector

node:combine-vector.title: Combine Vector
node:combine-vector.tagline: Perfect for combining individual float values into a vector (vec2, vec3, or vec4)
node:combine-vector.description: Combines individual float values into a vector. The node takes four float inputs (x, y, z, w) and outputs a vec4, but the output type can be configured to vec2 or vec3 as needed. The compiler handles type promotion/demotion based on how the output is used. This is the inverse operation of Split Vector and is essential for constructing vectors from individual components, creating coordinates from separate values, or assembling color values from individual channels.

inputs.name: x
inputs.description: The x component of the output vector

inputs.name: y
inputs.description: The y component of the output vector

inputs.name: z
inputs.description: The z component of the output vector

inputs.name: w
inputs.description: The w component of the output vector

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The combined vector (type promoted/demoted by compiler as needed)

node:bayer-dither.title: Bayer Dither
node:bayer-dither.tagline: Ideal for applying Bayer dithering to reduce banding artifacts and create ordered dither patterns
node:bayer-dither.description: Applies Bayer dithering to a float value using fragment coordinates to create an ordered dither pattern. Bayer dithering uses a threshold matrix to add controlled noise that breaks up banding artifacts in gradients and color transitions. The dithering strength and pixel size can be configured to control the intensity and scale of the dither pattern. This is particularly useful for reducing color banding in gradients, especially when working with limited color depth or when creating retro/vintage aesthetics that benefit from dithering artifacts.

inputs.name: in
inputs.description: The input value to apply dithering to

inputs.name: fragCoord
inputs.description: Fragment coordinates for dithering pattern calculation

inputs.name: resolution
inputs.description: Screen resolution for dithering calculations

outputs.name: out
outputs.description: The dithered value with Bayer pattern applied

node:tone-mapping.title: Tone Mapping
node:tone-mapping.tagline: Perfect for adjusting exposure, contrast, and saturation for final color correction
node:tone-mapping.description: Applies tone mapping adjustments to color values, including exposure (brightness), contrast, and saturation. Exposure multiplies the color values to adjust overall brightness. Contrast centers the values around 0.5 and scales them to increase or decrease contrast. Saturation adjusts color intensity by mixing the color with its luminance (grayscale version). These adjustments are essential for final color correction and achieving the desired look. node:final-output.description: Marks the final output node for the shader, indicating where the rendering pipeline ends. This is a terminal node with no outputs - it marks the end of the computation graph. The node accepts a vec3 RGB color input, and the compiler uses this input connection to determine the final shader output. The compiler automatically handles type conversion if a different type is connected (float becomes grayscale, vec2/vec4 are converted appropriately). This node is required in every shader graph to define the final output. Only one Final Output node should be present in a graph, and it serves as the entry point for the compiled shader code.
